section_title: CHAPTER II. Concerning the Subject of the Theology of Cases, Which Is the Conscience of Man
PRECEPTS.
RULES.
I. Conscience is a power of the practical intellect in a rational creature, determining concerning things done.
II. The natural state of conscience in every man is such that it is placed in a middle position between God and man, in such a way that it is below God and above man.
III. A good conscience is such either by creation, or by regeneration, that is, by re-creation.
IV. The evil conscience of man is either dead or awakened.
DISSERTATION Concerning the Most Base of All Baseness, Which Is Sin.

First, the baseness of sin consists in this: that its form is an aversion from God, who is the supreme Good, and a conversion to evil, which corrupt man regards under the appearance and guise of good.
Second, the effects of sin are of all things most base and most harmful.
Third, the mother of sin is most base.
Fourth, let us see how base is the nurse of sin.
Fifth, let us institute a comparison of the sinful man and the Christian, so that it may better appear how base sin is.
Finally, let us consider in particular how base are these and those sins.
V. For acquiring a good conscience, three means are required: namely, diligent preparation, application of the remedy, and reformation of the conscience.
VI. He who wishes to preserve a good conscience must remove the impediments and apply the nourishments.

CHAPTER I. Concerning the End of the Theology of Cases, Which Is the Tranquillity of the Tempted Conscience
PRECEPTS.
RULES.
I. The Theology of Cases is a part of practical theology, concerning the pacifying of the conscience of a tempted man.
II. The Theology of Cases is to be sought from the one Word of God alone.
III. In the preliminary cognition of the end, the Casuist ought to consider in what thing the tranquillity of conscience is situated, and how manifold temptation is.
Rule 1. Temptation is either unto good, or unto evil. The former is called the temptation of probation, the latter of seduction.
Rule 2. The Devil, the world, and the flesh often intermingle with divine temptations the temptation of security and desperation.
Rule 3. God tempts the elect as a father tempts his sons, and that unto the glory of His name and their eternal salvation.
Rule 4. Those who are tempted are either elect or reprobate. It is therefore false—this prejudice of the world—that every tempted man is reprobate: such as was the judgment of Job’s friends.

Objection. Non-being has no accidents. Natural theology is a non-being. Therefore, it has no accidents, and consequently, no method of its own should be established:
